expanded_description: Derived units are measurements created by combining SI base units through mathematical operations. They quantify physical quantities that arise from relationships between fundamental quantities.

core_concept.principle: Derived units are formed by multiplying, dividing, or raising base units to powers according to the physical relationships that define the quantities being measured.
core_concept.explanation: While base units measure fundamental quantities like length, mass, and time, most quantities in physics are defined by relationships between these fundamentals. Derived units express these relationships mathematically. For example, speed is defined as distance divided by time, so its unit (m/s) is derived by dividing the meter by the second. Understanding how derived units are built helps you understand the physics behind the measurements.

image.alt: Diagram showing how derived units are built from base units
image.caption: Derived units are combinations of base units that express physical relationships

sections.introduction: Most quantities in physics are not fundamental—they're defined by relationships between fundamental quantities. Their units are therefore derived from base units.

key_concept.definition: Derived units are units of measurement obtained by combining SI base units using multiplication, division, or exponentiation according to the algebraic relationships that define physical quantities.
key_concept.context: There are only seven base units, but infinitely many possible derived units. Every quantity in physics that isn't a base quantity has a derived unit. Some derived units have special names (like Newton for force), while others are simply written as combinations of base units.

principles.statement: Every derived unit can be expressed as a combination of the seven SI base units.
principles.application: This provides consistency—all measurements ultimately trace back to the same foundation.
principles.example: Speed (m/s), area (m²), density (kg/m³), force (kg·m/s²), energy (kg·m²/s²) all reduce to combinations of meter, kilogram, and second.

principles.statement: The structure of a derived unit mirrors the mathematical definition of the quantity.
principles.application: Understanding the units helps you understand and remember the physics.
principles.example: Velocity = distance/time, so velocity units = m/s. Acceleration = velocity/time = (m/s)/s = m/s². Force = mass × acceleration = kg × m/s² = kg·m/s².

principles.statement: Common derived units are given special names for convenience, but they still reduce to base units.
principles.application: Makes communication easier while maintaining connection to fundamentals.
principles.example: Newton (N) = kg·m/s², Joule (J) = kg·m²/s², Watt (W) = kg·m²/s³, Pascal (Pa) = kg/(m·s²).

image.alt: Flowchart showing how base units combine to form derived units
image.caption: Physical definitions determine how base units combine to form derived units

sections.section_title: Common Derived Units Without Special Names
sections.introduction: Many derived units are simply written as combinations of base units without receiving special names. These are among the most common in everyday physics.

classifications.behavior: Quantifies the amount of surface covered.

examples.explanation: Rectangle: Area = length × width = 5 m × 3 m = 15 m². The unit m² comes from multiplying meters by meters.
Square kilometer (km²), square centimeter (cm²), square millimeter (mm²). Note: 1 km² = (1000 m)² = 1,000,000 m².

classifications.note: When squaring a unit with a prefix, the prefix is also squared: (10³ m)² = 10⁶ m².

classifications.behavior: Quantifies the amount of space occupied.

examples.explanation: Rectangular box: Volume = length × width × height = 2 m × 3 m × 4 m = 24 m³.
Cubic centimeter (cm³), liter (L = 0.001 m³ = 1000 cm³), milliliter (mL = 1 cm³).

classifications.note: The liter (L) is technically a derived unit equal to 1 dm³ = 0.001 m³, but it's so common it's treated almost like a base unit for volume.

characteristics: Base unit combination: m/s or m·s⁻¹
classifications.behavior: Describes how fast position changes with time.

examples.explanation: Speed = distance/time = 100 m / 20 s = 5 m/s.
Kilometers per hour (km/h), centimeters per second (cm/s). To convert km/h to m/s: divide by 3.6.

classifications.note: Velocity and speed have the same units (m/s) but velocity includes direction while speed doesn't.

characteristics: Derived by: velocity ÷ time or (distance ÷ time) ÷ time
Measures rate of change of velocity
Base unit combination: m/s² or m·s⁻²

examples.explanation: Acceleration = change in velocity / time = (10 m/s - 0 m/s) / 2 s = 5 m/s².
Earth's gravitational acceleration: g = 9.8 m/s² (objects accelerate downward at this rate when falling).

classifications.note: The unit m/s² means 'meters per second, per second'—velocity changes by this many m/s every second.

characteristics: Base unit combination: kg/m³ or kg·m⁻³
classifications.behavior: Describes how much mass is packed into a given volume.

examples.explanation: Density = mass/volume = 500 kg / 0.2 m³ = 2500 kg/m³.
Water: 1000 kg/m³ (or 1 g/cm³), air: ~1.2 kg/m³, iron: 7870 kg/m³, gold: 19,300 kg/m³.
Gram per cubic centimeter (g/cm³) is also common. 1 g/cm³ = 1000 kg/m³.

classifications.behavior: Describes how many times something happens per second.

examples.explanation: Middle C note: 261.6 Hz (the sound wave oscillates 261.6 times per second).
North American electricity: 60 Hz (current alternates direction 60 times per second).

classifications.note: Hertz is a special name for s⁻¹. 1 Hz = 1/s = 1 cycle per second.

image.alt: Table showing common derived units and their base unit equivalents
image.caption: Common derived units built from length, mass, and time base units

sections.introduction: Some derived units are used so frequently in physics that they've been given special names. Despite having names, they're still combinations of base units.

key_concept.definition: Named derived units have special designations for convenience, but each can be expressed in terms of SI base units. These names honor scientists and make communication easier.
key_concept.context: Learning these special names and understanding what they represent in base units helps you work with physics formulas and understand relationships between quantities.

characteristics: 1 N = force needed to accelerate 1 kg at 1 m/s²

examples.explanation: F = ma = 10 kg × 2 m/s² = 20 kg·m/s² = 20 N. Force of 20 Newtons.
Your weight is the force of gravity on your mass. If m = 60 kg: Weight = mg = 60 kg × 9.8 m/s² = 588 N.
Apple falling: ~1 N, pushing a door: ~10 N, car engine: ~5000 N.

classifications.note: The Newton is fundamental in mechanics. Every force, tension, friction, weight has units of Newtons.

characteristics: 1 J = work done by 1 N force over 1 m distance
classifications.behavior: Quantifies the capacity to do work or cause change.

examples.explanation: Work = Force × distance = 10 N × 5 m = 50 N·m = 50 J.
KE = ½mv² = ½(2 kg)(3 m/s)² = ½(2)(9) kg·m²/s² = 9 J.
Climbing one stair: ~1800 J, AAA battery: ~5000 J, candy bar: ~1,000,000 J (1 MJ).

classifications.note: Joule is used for all forms of energy: kinetic, potential, thermal, electrical, chemical. Energy is always measured in Joules in SI.

characteristics: 1 W = 1 J of energy per second
classifications.behavior: Describes how quickly energy is used or transferred.

examples.explanation: Power = Energy/time = 1000 J / 10 s = 100 J/s = 100 W.
LED bulb: 10 W, laptop: 50 W, hair dryer: 1500 W, car engine: 75,000 W (75 kW).
Walking: ~100 W, running: ~500 W, professional cyclist: ~400 W sustained.

classifications.note: Your electric bill is measured in kilowatt-hours (kWh): energy = power × time. 1 kWh = 1000 W × 3600 s = 3,600,000 J.

characteristics: 1 Pa = 1 N of force over 1 m² area
classifications.behavior: Quantifies force distributed over an area.

examples.explanation: Pressure = Force/Area = 200 N / 0.5 m² = 400 N/m² = 400 Pa.
Standard atmospheric pressure: 101,325 Pa = 101.325 kPa ≈ 1 atmosphere.
Car tire: ~220,000 Pa = 220 kPa = 32 psi (pounds per square inch).

classifications.note: Pascals are small, so kilopascals (kPa) are common. Weather reports often use hectopascals (hPa): 1 hPa = 100 Pa.

classifications.behavior: Describes repetition rate of periodic phenomena.

examples.explanation: Human hearing range: 20 Hz to 20,000 Hz (20 kHz). Middle C: 262 Hz.
Red light: ~4.3 × 10¹⁴ Hz, blue light: ~6.7 × 10¹⁴ Hz.
CPU clock speed: 3 GHz (3 billion cycles per second).

characteristics: 1 C = charge flowing when 1 A current flows for 1 s
classifications.behavior: Quantifies the amount of electrical charge.

examples.explanation: Charge = Current × time = 2 A × 10 s = 20 A·s = 20 C.
One electron: -1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ C. One coulomb = charge of ~6.24 × 10¹⁸ electrons.

characteristics: 1 V = 1 J of energy per coulomb of charge
classifications.behavior: Describes electrical potential energy per unit charge.

examples.explanation: AA battery: 1.5 V, car battery: 12 V, household outlet: 120 V (North America) or 230 V (Europe).
Voltage = Energy/Charge = 12 J / 2 C = 6 J/C = 6 V.

characteristics: 1 Ω = resistance when 1 V produces 1 A current
classifications.behavior: Quantifies opposition to electric current flow.

examples.explanation: V = IR. If V = 12 V and I = 3 A, then R = V/I = 12 V / 3 A = 4 Ω.
Wire: ~0.01 Ω, resistor: 100-10,000 Ω, human body: ~100,000 Ω.

principles.statement: Special names make communication easier but represent base unit combinations.
principles.application: You can always express named units in base units if needed for calculations.
principles.example: Force: 50 N = 50 kg·m/s². Energy: 100 J = 100 kg·m²/s². Power: 75 W = 75 kg·m²/s³.

principles.statement: Most named units honor scientists who made major contributions to that field.
principles.example: Using 'Newtons' reminds us of Isaac Newton's laws of motion. 'Joules' honors James Joule's work on energy.

image.caption: Common named derived units and their base unit expressions

sections.introduction: Understanding how to construct derived units from physical definitions helps you remember units and check your work.

key_concept.definition: Derived units follow directly from the mathematical relationships that define physical quantities. If you know the defining equation, you can determine the units.
key_concept.context: This is a powerful tool: even if you forget a unit, you can reconstruct it from the formula.

process_flow.description: Find the formula that defines the quantity you're measuring.
applications: Density: ρ = m/V (mass divided by volume)
Pressure: P = F/A (force divided by area)

process_flow.description: Replace each variable with its SI unit.
process_flow.mechanism: Use base units or previously established derived units.
process_flow.result: Unit expression for the new quantity.

process_flow.description: Perform algebraic operations on the units (multiply, divide, cancel).
applications: Pressure: kg·m/s² ÷ m² = kg·m·s⁻²·m⁻² = kg/(m·s²) = kg·m⁻¹·s⁻² = Pa
Work: Force × distance = (kg·m/s²) × m = kg·m²/s² = J

process_flow.description: See if the unit combination has a standard name.
process_flow.result: Unit expressed in simplest or most conventional form.

worked_examples.title: Deriving the Unit of Force
worked_examples.problem: Use Newton's Second Law (F = ma) to derive the SI unit of force.

step_by_step.explanation: F = ma (force equals mass times acceleration)

step_by_step.step: Identify units of m and a
step_by_step.explanation: Mass: kilogram (kg). Acceleration: m/s² (meters per second squared)
Unit of F = unit of m × unit of a = kg × m/s² = kg·m/s²
kg·m/s² is called the Newton (N)

worked_examples.final_answer: The SI unit of force is kg·m/s², which is called the Newton (N). 1 N = 1 kg·m/s².
worked_examples.concept_applied: Derived units follow directly from the defining equations of physical quantities.

worked_examples.title: Deriving the Unit of Energy
worked_examples.problem: Energy is defined as force times distance (W = Fd). Derive the SI unit of energy.

step_by_step.explanation: W = Fd (work/energy equals force times distance)
Force: N = kg·m/s². Distance: m (meter)
Unit of W = N × m = (kg·m/s²) × m = kg·m²/s²
kg·m²/s² is called the Joule (J). Also written as N·m.

worked_examples.final_answer: The SI unit of energy is kg·m²/s² or N·m, which is called the Joule (J).
worked_examples.concept_applied: Complex derived units can be built from simpler derived units (energy from force and distance).

worked_examples.title: Deriving the Unit of Power
worked_examples.problem: Power is energy per unit time (P = E/t). Derive the SI unit of power.

step_by_step.explanation: P = E/t (power equals energy divided by time)
Energy: J = kg·m²/s². Time: s (second)
Unit of P = J/s = (kg·m²/s²)/s = kg·m²/s³
kg·m²/s³ or J/s is called the Watt (W)

worked_examples.final_answer: The SI unit of power is kg·m²/s³ or J/s, which is called the Watt (W).
worked_examples.concept_applied: Derived units can be built from other derived units (power from energy and time).

worked_examples.title: Deriving the Unit of Density
worked_examples.problem: Density is mass per unit volume (ρ = m/V). What is its SI unit?

step_by_step.explanation: ρ = m/V (density equals mass divided by volume)
Mass: kg (kilogram). Volume: m³ (cubic meter)
Unit of ρ = kg/m³
No special name. Written as kg/m³ or kg·m⁻³.

worked_examples.final_answer: The SI unit of density is kg/m³ (kilograms per cubic meter).
worked_examples.concept_applied: Not all derived units have special names—many are simply written as combinations of base units.

image.caption: Deriving units: start with the defining equation, substitute units, simplify

sections.introduction: Derived units provide a powerful tool for checking whether equations and calculations are correct through dimensional analysis.

key_concept.definition: Dimensional analysis uses the principle that both sides of any valid equation must have the same units. If units don't match, the equation is wrong.
key_concept.context: This is one of the most useful error-checking tools in physics. Before solving a problem numerically, check that the units work out.

principles.statement: In any valid physics equation, the units on both sides must be identical.
principles.application: If you get different units on left and right sides, you've made an error.
principles.example: d = vt. Left side: m (distance). Right side: (m/s) × s = m. Units match ✓. If you wrote d = vt², right side would be (m/s) × s² = m·s, not meters. This alerts you to the error.

principles.principle: Units Add/Subtract Only with Same Dimensions
principles.statement: You can only add or subtract quantities with the same units.
principles.application: Prevents nonsensical operations like adding mass to length.
principles.example: Valid: 5 m + 3 m = 8 m. Invalid: 5 m + 3 kg = ??? (can't add length to mass). If an equation requires this, it's wrong.

principles.statement: When multiplying or dividing quantities, multiply or divide their units.
principles.application: Allows tracking units through complex calculations.
principles.example: Force = mass × acceleration = 10 kg × 2 m/s² = 20 kg·m/s² = 20 N. Units multiply: kg × (m/s²) = kg·m/s².

worked_examples.title: Checking Equation Validity with Units
worked_examples.problem: A student writes: "Kinetic energy = ½mv". Check if this equation can be correct using dimensional analysis.

step_by_step.explanation: Kinetic energy has units of Joules: J = kg·m²/s²
½ is dimensionless. m = kg, v = m/s. So right side = kg × (m/s) = kg·m/s
Left: kg·m²/s². Right: kg·m/s. These don't match!
The equation must be wrong. Units don't agree.
The correct formula is KE = ½mv². Units: kg × (m/s)² = kg × m²/s² = kg·m²/s² ✓

worked_examples.final_answer: The equation KE = ½mv cannot be correct because the units don't match. The left side is kg·m²/s² but the right side is kg·m/s. The correct equation is KE = ½mv².
worked_examples.concept_applied: Dimensional analysis catches errors even without knowing numerical values.

worked_examples.title: Using Units to Remember Formulas
worked_examples.problem: You can't remember if pressure is force/area or area/force. Use dimensional analysis to figure it out.

step_by_step.explanation: Pressure is measured in Pascals: Pa = N/m²
Pa = N/m² = (kg·m/s²)/m² = kg/(m·s²)
Force/area = N/m² = Pa ✓. This matches!
Area/force = m²/N = m²/(kg·m/s²) = m²·s²/(kg·m) = m·s²/kg. This is NOT pressure.

worked_examples.final_answer: Pressure = force/area (not area/force). You can verify this because Pa = N/m².
worked_examples.concept_applied: Knowing units helps you remember or reconstruct formulas.

worked_examples.title: Finding Unknown Exponents
worked_examples.problem: The formula for kinetic energy is KE = Cmvⁿ where C is a constant. Use dimensional analysis to find n.

step_by_step.explanation: KE has units of energy: J = kg·m²/s²
C is dimensionless. m = kg, v = m/s. Right side = kg × (m/s)ⁿ = kg × mⁿ/sⁿ = kg·mⁿ·s⁻ⁿ
kg·m²·s⁻² = kg·mⁿ·s⁻ⁿ
For kg: 1 = 1 ✓. For m: 2 = n, so n = 2. For s: -2 = -n, so n = 2 ✓

worked_examples.final_answer: n = 2. The formula is KE = Cmv² (and C = ½).
worked_examples.concept_applied: Dimensional analysis can determine unknown exponents in formulas.

sections.introduction: Understanding common errors helps you avoid them and strengthens your grasp of how derived units work.

classifications.value: Forgetting to square or cube the prefix
classifications.behavior: When converting area or volume, the conversion factor is squared or cubed.

examples.explanation: Thinking 1 km² = 1000 m². Wrong! 1 km = 1000 m, so 1 km² = (1000 m)² = 1,000,000 m².
1 km² = (10³ m)² = 10⁶ m². The exponent on the unit affects the conversion factor.

classifications.note: When squaring or cubing a quantity with a prefix, the prefix is also squared or cubed.

classifications.value: Using kg for weight instead of N
characteristics: Weight is a force (N), not a mass (kg)
classifications.behavior: People say 'weighs 70 kg' but technically weight is the force = mg ≈ 686 N.

examples.explanation: Mass = 70 kg (amount of matter). Weight = mg = 70 kg × 9.8 m/s² = 686 N (gravitational force).

classifications.note: In physics, be precise: mass in kg, weight (force) in N. In everyday speech, people often use 'weight' to mean mass.

classifications.type: Forgetting to Convert to Base Units
characteristics: Using km and m in the same calculation
classifications.behavior: Leads to wrong answers—units must match.

examples.explanation: Density = 500 g / 2 m³ = 250 g/m³. But SI unit is kg/m³! Should convert: 500 g = 0.5 kg, so ρ = 0.5 kg / 2 m³ = 0.25 kg/m³.

classifications.note: Convert all quantities to SI base units before calculating for consistency.

classifications.value: Canceling units that don't actually cancel

examples.explanation: Speed = 100 m / 20 s = 5 m/s (meters divided by seconds). Work = 10 N × 5 m = 50 N·m = 50 J (Newtons times meters).

classifications.note: Track units carefully through every step, treating them like algebraic variables.

summary: Derived units are formed by combining SI base units through multiplication, division, or exponentiation according to the physical relationships that define quantities. Common derived units without special names include area (m²), volume (m³), speed (m/s), acceleration (m/s²), and density (kg/m³). Many frequently-used derived units have special names: Newton (N = kg·m/s²) for force, Joule (J = kg·m²/s²) for energy, Watt (W = kg·m²/s³) for power, Pascal (Pa = kg/(m·s²)) for pressure, and Hertz (Hz = s⁻¹) for frequency. Derived units reflect the mathematical definitions of physical quantities—if you know the defining equation, you can determine the units. This makes derived units powerful tools for checking work through dimensional analysis: valid equations must have matching units on both sides. Understanding how derived units are constructed from base units helps you remember formulas, check calculations, and understand the relationships between physical quantities. All measurements in physics ultimately reduce to combinations of the seven SI base units, creating a coherent, universal system for scientific communication.
